INTRODUCTION 

 
The  Government  of  Uzbekistan  has  demonstrated  its  dedication  to  improving  national 
2. 
education, which will play a pivotal role in achieving economic transition and fostering national

3.

Macroeconomic Context 

 
A. 
 
Since  its  independence  in  1991,  Uzbekistan  has  adopted  a  gradual  approach  to 
5. 
structural  adjustment  and  macroeconomic  stabilization  as  well  as  to  sector  reforms.  The 
country’s  rich  endowment  in  natural  resources—Uzbekistan  is  one  of  the  world’s  largest 
producers of cotton, gold, and natural gas—and the Government’s ability to earn hard currency 
from exports allowed some degree of freedom with respect to the pace of institutional change 
and  structural  adjustment.  Unlike  the  other  Central  Asian  republics  of  the  former  Soviet  Union 
(FSU), Uzbekistan avoided a dramatic economic downturn in the post-independence years, and 
was  able  to  minimize  short-term  social  unrest  associated  with  the  transition  to  a  market 
economy.  
 
6. 
As  part  of  this  gradualist  approach,  the  institutional  framework  necessary  for  a  market 
economy to operate is progressively being put in place. Prices of consumer goods have been 
liberalized,  privatization  of  small  enterprises  and  housing  has  been  completed,  and 
corporatization of medium- and large-scale state-owned enterprises has been initiated under a 
vast privatization program. Fiscal and public sector management has improved, although good 
governance  remains  undermined  by  a  system  of  excessive  control  and  regulation.  The 
Government  took  significant  steps  to  augment  revenues  by  introducing  a  value-added tax by 
and  increasing  land  and  excise  taxes.  On  the  expenditure  side,  administrative  expenses  were 
cut 
foodstuffs, 
through  administrative  downsizing,  while  direct  subsidies  on 
transportation, and housing were largely removed.  
 
7. 
Agriculture remains the key sector for Uzbekistan’s economic development, accounting 
for  roughly  35%  of  gross  domestic  product  (GDP),  60%  of  exports,  and  35%  of  employment. 
State and collective farms are progressively being transformed into private family-owned farms 
in an attempt to improve market responsiveness and increase agricultural yields. New policies in 
the  rural  sector  promote  self-sufficiency  in  food  production  and  export  expansion,  essentially 
through  shifting  from  cotton  monoculture  to  food  crops.  At  the  same  time,  state  agricultural 
revenues  are  being  largely  redistributed  to  finance  investments  in  other sectors, especially in 
import-substitution industries.  
 
8. 
Despite  the  Government’s  attempts  to  boost  investment  in  domestic  industry,  industrial 
growth  since  independence  has  been  very  modest,  and  industry’s  share  of  GDP  actually 
declined from 22% in 1993 to 15% in 2000. This weak performance reflects structural rigidities 
in  the  economy,  distortions  in  factor  markets,  and  import  restrictions.  In  contrast,  the  service 
sector expanded considerably with the relative stable macroeconomic environment. Wholesale 
and  retail  activities  thrived,  especially  in  the  capital,  Tashkent,  and  the  tourism  sector  has 
developed  rapidly.  The  sector  distribution  of  economic  output  and  the  rapid  changes  affecting 
economic  activity  have  important  implications  for  labor  market  requirements  and  hence  for 
education  and  training  reforms.  Most  importantly,  there  is  a  need  to  strengthen  the  general 
content  of  instruction,  as  opposed  to  highly  specialized  training,  thereby  promoting  the 
acquisition of skills and knowledge applicable to a large number of industries and enhancing the 
flexibility of the workforce. 
 
9. 
Regarding  macroeconomic  policies  and  stabilization,  the  Government  performed 
relatively  well  in  maintaining  both  internal  and  external  balance  in  the  face  of  successive 
external shocks in the 1990s, including the loss of budgetary and trade transfers from Moscow, 
the  Russian  financial  crisis,  and  declining  prices  in  international  commodity  markets.  In  the 

  

3

period 1991-95, GDP fell by 20%, a sizeable shock, but less dramatic than that experienced by 
other CARs. Positive growth resumed in 1996 at an average rate of 4.5%. According to official 
statistics,  in  2000,  GDP  growth  was  4.0%,  the  inflation  rate  was  28%,  and  the  trade  surplus 
exceeded 0.8% of GDP. The country has thus been able to combine relatively steady economic 
growth with acceptable inflation levels and current account deficits since the mid-1990s. These 
positive indicators, however, largely reflect the Government’s tight control over the economy.  
 
10. 
Indeed,  the  most  challenging  task  within  macroeconomic  adjustments  remains  the 
liberalization  of  foreign  trade  and  exchange  regimes.  The  Government  initially  stated  that  it 
would not seek International Monetary Fund (IMF) assistance in completing the macroeconomic 
stabilization, as it wanted to implement the reforms at its own pace to minimize the social costs 
to  the  population  at  large.  A  series  of  moderate  steps  were  introduced  in  2000  and  2001  to 
liberalize  access  to  and  sale  of  foreign  exchange  and  to  expand  foreign  trade  in  consumer 
goods. However, uncertainty about the Government’s commitment to achieve full liberalization 
of the currency, trade, and investment markets led to the de facto closure of the IMF Resident 
Mission in April 2001. In parallel, Uzbekistan experienced a severe deterioration in its terms of 
trade, caused by a drop in cotton and gold prices. Recently, the Government encountered rising 
debt-service payments, and balance of payments pressures.  
 
11. 
In  this  macroeconomic  context,  and  in  the  aftermath  of  the  events  of  11  September 
2001,  which  raised  increased  international  attention  regarding  Uzbekistan’s  security  and 
stability, negotiations with IMF resumed. An IMF mission visited Uzbekistan in December 2001 
for  discussions  with  the  Government  on  a  comprehensive  program  of  macroeconomic 
stabilization and structural reform to be monitored through a staff monitored program. The staff 
monitored  program  was  declared  effective  in  February  2002.  Its  key  elements  include—inter 
alia—(i)  elimination  of  all  restrictions  on  access  to  foreign  exchange  for  current  account 
transactions, (ii) reform of the state procurement system for raw cotton and grain, (iii) measures 
to  reduce  the  number  of  state  monopolies  and  monopoly  products,  and  (iv)  preparation  of  a 
statistics  law  leading  to  the  establishment  of  an  independent  statistical  agency.  Based  on  the 
IMF’s  positive  assessment  of  the  status  of  reforms,  the  monitoring  period  under  the  SMP  was 
extended until 31 August 2002 and preliminary discussions for an economic program that could 
be supported by the IMF were initiated. 
 
12. 
The  Government  continues  to  place  high  priority  on  human  development  and  social 
protection, and is conscious that acceleration of the liberalization process may be painful for the 
population at large in the short term if it is not well managed and mitigated by appropriate safety 
nets. Some reform measures will result in the erosion of real income for pensioners and other 
vulnerable groups of society, as well as layoffs due to the restructuring of collective farms and 
industrial state-owned enterprises. This, in turn, may jeopardize access to basic social services 
including  health,  education,  and  housing.  In  discussing  the  ESDP,  and  more  generally  the 
program  lending  approach,  the  Government  stressed  the  high  and  increasing  level  of  social 
spending, especially for the education sector, required to ease the social cost of the adjustment.  
 
B. 
 

Sector Description  

1. 

Structure of Education  

 
13. 
The  Soviet  model  of  education,  which  emphasized  a  high  number  of  compulsory 
subjects  in  general  education  and  highly  specialized  programs  in  technical  and  higher 
education,  is  no  longer  consistent  with  the  need  for  greater  flexibility  required  in  a  modern 
market  economy.  Moving  away  from  such  a  model,  the  NPPT  foresees  major  changes  in  the 

  

4

structure of Uzbekistan’s education system during the period from school year (SY) 1999 until 
SY2005.  
 
14. 
First,  compulsory  education  is  being  extended  to  12  years,  maintaining  age  6  as  the 
minimum  school-starting  age  and  adopting  a  4-5-3  pattern.  As  shown  in  Appendix  2,  this 
sequence  will  consist  of  4  years  of  primary,  5  years  of  junior  secondary,  and  3  years  of  SSE. 
The  previous  4-5-2  structure  will  thus  be  progressively  phased  out,  with  SSE  extended  to  a 
three-year program by adding grade 12.  
 
15. 
Second, while the previous system was highly fragmented  – characterized by numerous 
tracks  and  types  of  institutions—the  education  structure  is  being  streamlined  and  simplified. 
Basic education, referring to the nine years of instruction covering primary and junior secondary 
education,  will  be  delivered  in  general  schools  only.  SSE  will  comprise  only  two  types  of 
institutions:  academic  lyceums  (ALs)  and  professional  colleges  (PCs).  ALs  have  a  general 
academic  focus  and  prepare  students  for  tertiary  education,  while  PCs  emphasize  technical 
skills  and  prepare  students  for  entry  into  the  workforce.  All  technical  and  vocational 
establishments  will  be  gradually  closed  or  converted  into  professional  colleges.  In  higher 
education,  numerous  courses  and  diploma  programs  will  be  progressively  eliminated  and 
replaced by four-year bachelor’s programs, followed by two-year master’s programs.  
 
Third,  the  orientation  of  compulsory  education  will  undergo  a  fundamental  shift  away 
16. 
from  general  education  towards  technical  and  vocational  education  (TVE),  with  the  network  of 
PCs  expected  to  account  for  as  much  as  90  %  of  SSE  enrolments.  In  parallel,  education  in 
general (i.e., academic) subjects will be included in a strengthened core curriculum introduced 
in PCs, and the number of specializations offered will be adjusted to demand.  
 
17. 
As  indicated  in  Appendix  3,  basic  education  currently  accounts  for  approximately 5.7 
million students (2.6 million enrolled in grades 1-4 and 3.1 million in grades 5-9), 9,600 schools, 
and  410,000  teachers.  Although  the  implementation  of  the  new  structure  will  have  no  major 
impact on total quantities of teacher personnel in basic education, friction is likely to arise from 
substantial internal reallocations. In view of demographic trends (which show a slight diminution 
of the school age population), and given the fact that grades 10 and 11 will no longer be offered 
in basic schools, there may be an overall surplus of facilities, enrollment capacity, and teachers 
in  the  subsector.  At  the  same  time,  there  is  an  emerging  qualitative  or  field-by-field mismatch 
between the supply of and demand for teachers. A significant number of vacancies cannot be 
filled or must be filled by unqualified personnel, and there are persistent shortages of teachers 
for certain subjects and in remote rural areas. 
 
18. 
In terms of raw enrolments, the NPPT will mark the most dramatic change for the SSE 
subsector. Current Government plans call for the establishment of 1,611 PCs with an enrollment 
capacity of 1,020,000 students and 181 ALs with an enrollment capacity of 80,000 by the year 
2010. SSE expansion will involve the construction of new campuses and  boarding facilities as 
well  as  the  conversion  of  former  technical  secondary  schools  into  PCs.  The  Government 
foresees that the new SSE system will require a total of about 120,000 teachers, whereas only 
75,000 are currently teaching in corresponding grades. Most teachers serving in technical and 
vocational  institutions  in  grades  10  and  11  in  general  schools  will  be  retrained  to  assume 
positions in the new type of institution. The Government also intends to attract young graduates 
as well as professionals from outside the education sphere to fill vacancies in ALs and PCs.  
 
19. 
The  higher  education  subsector  consists  of  over  60  institutions  (specialized  institutes 
and  universities,  usually  composed  of  several  faculties)  enrolling  roughly  196,000  students, 

  

5

down from 230,000 in 1994. The Government does not expect any increase in higher education 
enrollments due to the vocationalization of SSE. A rationalization of the subsector, by grouping 
higher  education  institutions  and  reducing  courses  and  programs  offered  in  line  with  actual 
demand, is under way.  
 

2. 

Access to and Participation in Education 

 
20. 
The uninterrupted political commitment of both the FSU and the independent Republic of 
Uzbekistan to support and adequately finance education resulted in considerable achievements 
in  terms  of  the  population’s  access  to  and  participation  in  education.  The  adult  literacy  rate  of 
the  national  population  is  estimated  at  99%.5  The  labor  force  is  well  educated  and  qualified: 
82%  of  workers  have  completed  basic  education,  of  whom  34%  have  completed  senior 
secondary or higher education. As a result, Uzbekistan’s well-developed human resource base 
is considered a major asset for its future economic development. 
 
21.  While  official  statistics  often  report  comprehensive  basic  education  coverage  with  only 
small disparities between rural and urban areas or between genders, there are indications that 
access  to  education  declined  in  the  past  decade.  According  to  UNICEF  (Trans  MONEE  2001 
Database) gross enrollment ratios decreased significantly between 1989 and 1999 at all levels 
of  education:  (i)  from  26%  to  16%  in  pre-primary  education,  (ii)  from  92%  to  88%  in  basic 
education,  (iii)  from  67%  to  52%  in  senior  secondary  education,  and  (iv)  from  15%  to  6%  in 
higher education. To a certain extent, the decline in participation in education reflects the surge 
in  school  dropouts  that  occurred  in  the  years  following  independence,  especially  in  the  rural 
areas.  Dropout  is  attributable  to  both  economic  reasons  (rising  direct  and  indirect  costs  of 
schooling),  and  poor  preparedness  for  primary  education  due  to  a  sharp  fall  in  preschool 
attendance.6   
 
22. 
Other  important  problems  need  to  be  addressed  in  terms  of  equity  in  access  to 
education,  in  particular  with  respect  to  the  situation  of  girls  and  ethnic  minorities.  Gender 
disparities become more prominent as one moves upwards in educational levels. Women make 
up 39% of the total enrollment in higher education, declining to 25% for master’s courses and 
12% for doctoral courses. Females’ access to technical education remains restricted, especially 
in the scientific fields. As a result of these disparities, women tend to be employed in relatively 
few  sectors  (e.g.,  education,  health,  food  processing)  and  have  far  fewer  opportunities  for 
career  advancement.  The  education  of  children  from  ethnic  and  linguistic  minorities  is  an 
important and sensitive policy issue. At present, over 10% of the schools of the country provide 
instruction  in  the  languages  of  ethnic  minorities  (Russian, Kazak, Tajik, Karakalpak, Turkmen, 
and  Kyrgyz),  accounting  for  about  15%  of  total  enrolments  in  basic  education.  So  far,  the 
Government  has  maintained  its  political  commitment  to  provide  basic  education  in  the  seven 
national  languages  (including  Uzbek).  However,  schools  for  minority  children  are  at  a 
disadvantage  in  terms  of  availability  of  instructional  materials  and  textbooks  in  national 
languages,  as  well  as  teacher  qualifications.  Opportunities  for  further  education  are  also 
reduced for these children, who are not well equipped to enter the mainstream of Uzbekistan’s 
SSE, conducted exclusively in the Uzbek language.

3. 

Management of Education 

 
23. 
Uzbekistan’s education sector does not perform well in terms of cost-effectiveness as a 
result of rigidities from inherited central planning and budgeting systems. The education system 
is characterized by suboptimal utilization of public resources, reflected in small class and school 
sizes,  plus  low  efficiency  ratios  and  teaching  loads.  Structural and institutional changes in the 
system  are  necessary  to  modernize  sector  management  practices,  support  community 
participation  and  nongovernmental  funding  of  education,  and  improve  overall  efficiency  and 
equity in the utilization of educational resources  (physical, human, and financial). 
 
24. 
Policymaking in education is the domain of the Social Complex of COM and the Office of 
the  President.  In  spite  of  recent  and  rather  modest  changes,  management  of  the  education 
sector still rests on planning and budgeting methods inherited from the FSU. Centrally defined 
norms and standards regulate the allocation of resources, leaving little flexibility for adjustment 
to  particular  situations.  Long-term  planning  of  capital  investment  and  projections  of  student 
numbers and staff requirements are undertaken by MOMES. Projections of enrollments in SSE 
and  higher  education  institutions  are  determined  on  the  basis  of  a  rigid  manpower  planning 
approach and static regional labor market analysis. MOMES is also the  agency responsible for 
preparing  and  releasing  official  education  statistics,  while  other  central  agencies,  including 
MOPE, MOHSSE, MOF, and MOL, maintain their own data collection and processing systems. 
Existing information systems appear fragmented, and statistics produced often lack consistency 
and relevance to policy. 
 
25.  MOPE  and  MOHSSE  are  responsible  for  implementing  national  policies  in  their 
respective  education  subsectors.  A  number  of  central  or  Republican  institutes  have  also  been 
established  with  varying  degrees  of  autonomy  vis-à-vis  the  two  ministries  to  oversee  the 
implementation of policies and programs in certain reform areas and subsectors. These include 
the  CSSE,  the  Republican  Testing  Center  (examinations  and  standard  setting),  Republican 
Education  Center  (development  of  curriculum  and  textbooks),  CIESD  (in-service  training  of 
school  teachers  and  administrators),  Central  Institute  for  Pedagogical  Research  (teaching 
methods and processes), and Institute for Problems of Higher Education.  
 
26.  With  the  NPPT,  the  Government  clearly  announced  its  intention  to  move  towards  a 
management system that promotes administrative decentralization and encourages community 
participation  and  local  initiative.  Financing  and  management  responsibilities  of  the  school 
system  are  being  increasingly  devolved  to  local  governments.  The  administration  of  preschool 
and  basic  education  institutions  is  under  the  dual  responsibility  of  the  regional  governments 
(hokimiyat) and MOPE through its 14 regional (oblast-level) and 214 district (raion-level) offices 
throughout  the  country.  Professional  colleges  are  administered  by  SSE  regional  offices 
reporting  to  both  CSSE  and  the  regional  governments.  With  a  few  exceptions,7  all  higher 
education  institutions  and  AL  (usually  attached  to  or  established  under  the  auspices  of  a 
university) are administered by MOHSSE. 
 
27.  Managerial procedures are being progressively overhauled, and educational institutions 
have  now  acquired  some  autonomy  in  making  decisions  on the allocation of resources. Most 
significant advances include the abolition of norms regulating the recruitment of school support

4. 

Content and Processes of Education  

 
28. 
The extent to which the knowledge, attitudes, and skills imparted by the education and 
training system are mastered by learners and contribute to the country’s economic development  
remains  largely  unknown  because  of  the  lack  of  pertinent  information  regarding  learning 
outcomes,  graduate  placement  in  the  job  market,  and  worker  productivity.  There  is,  however, 
evidence  that,  as  in  other  countries  of  the  FSU,  the  content,  processes,  and organization of 
Uzbekistan’s  education  system  should  be  revamped  to  better  serve  the  needs  of  changing 
economic,  social,  and  political  conditions.  The  NPPT  acknowledges  the  need  for  fundamental 
reorientation of the education system towards one that is more suited to the requirements of a 
market economy and, at the same time, can further national identity and democracy.  
 
29. 
Educational quality improvement, more particularly through the revision of curricula and 
textbook content, has been the overarching priority of education authorities since independence.  
The perceived low quality and insufficient relevance of education are attributable to a number of 
factors including outdated and ideologically biased curricula, non-interactive teaching methods, 
and poor quality instructional materials. In basic education, priority must be given to focusing the 
content  of  instruction  towards  core  competencies  and  to  better  preparing  students  for  lifelong 
trainability.  A  new  emphasis  on  inculcating  problem-solving ability and creativity is especially  
needed  in  this  respect.10  In  technical  and  higher  education,  broad-based  skills  acquisition 
should be emphasized to encourage graduates’ employability and flexibility in the context of an 
evolving market economy, where labor market demand cannot be predicted well. 
 
Government efforts in the area of quality improvement culminated with the preparation of 
30. 
educational  standards  for  basic  education,  SSE,  and,  more  recently,  higher  education. 
Standards  encompas s  all  aspects  related  to  the  organization  and  the  content  of  educational 
programs. The new basic education curriculum better reflects Uzbekistan’s history and culture, 
and integrates subjects such as economics, computer, and environmental education. In parallel, 
the new generation of latin-script textbooks is being introduced in a phased manner, a process 
that started in 1996 and is expected to be completed in SY2003. At the SSE level, the variety of 
courses requires larger efforts to develop new curricula and instructional materials. Curricula are 
still in an experimental phase, and the translation of foreign textbooks into Uzbek is the favored 
approach in the short run. A significant achievement in the TVE subsector is the streamlining of 
programs offered in PCs in around seven major fields: industry, transport and communications,

31. 
Efforts aimed at improving educational quality have been hampered by two factors: lack 
of  national  capacity  and  lack  of  financial  resources.  The  vast  majority  of  Uzbek  educators, 
curriculum  specialists,  and  textbook  authors  have  never  been  exposed  to  alternative 
approaches to teaching and international experiences in curriculum reform. Educational quality 
monitoring  systems  based  on  assessments  of  teaching  processes  and  learning  outcomes, 
rather than solely on input levels, should be developed. At the school level, resource constraints 
have  aggravated  common  problems  such  as  shortages  of  instructional  equipment  and 
materials,  as  well  as  the  distressed  physical  conditions  of  classrooms  and  school  buildings. 
School  environments  must  become  more  conductive  to  effective  learning,  especially  in 
economically disadvantaged areas.  
 

5. 

Teacher Education 

 
Both  pre-service  and  in-service  teacher  education  are  being  reformed  in  their  content 
32. 
and organization. As part of the new NPPT standards, all teachers are now required to obtain a 
Bachelor’s  level  degree  through  four  years  of  higher  education  and  must  receive  periodic 
recertification.  At  the  primary  level,  approximately  66,000  teachers  (equivalent  to  54%  of  the 
total  number  of  primary  school  teachers), most of them serving in rural schools, are presently 
considered to be underqualified by the Government. Only a limited proportion of these teachers, 
about 15%, have begun upgrading by means of correspondence studies with higher education 
institutions.  The  Government  considers  that  all  underqualified  teachers  should  receive  special 
upgrading  courses.  Moreover,  virtually  all  teachers  need  to  be  retrained  to  master  the  revised 
subject contents under the new curricula, and to gain experience in modern teaching methods.  
 
33. 
Preservice  teacher  education  comprises  a  variety  of  institutions  whose  roles  are  being 
redefined  in  line  with  the  new  educational  structure.  Pedagogical  colleges,  which  in  the  past 
trained the majority of primary school teachers,  will now be exclusively responsible for training 
teachers  of  preschool  and  “special  subjects”  (music,  gymnastics,  drawing,  and  labor).  The 
number  of  pedagogical  colleges  will  accordingly  be  reduced  from  38  to  25  by  2005. 
Postsecondary  teacher  education  institutions  comprise  the  5  institutes  of  pedagogy  (IPs),  the 
Tashkent  Pedagogical  University  and  16  faculties  of  pedagogy  (FPs).  In  general,  graduates 
from the IPs and the Tashkent Pedagogical University are employed mainly in basic education, 
while  those  from  the  FPs  usually  serve  in  SSE.  Pedagogical  colleges  and  institutes  report  to 
MOPE,  whereas  the  FPs  are  administered  by  MOHSSE.  A  priority  of  the  Government  is  to 
expand the enrolment capacity of the FPs to respond to the need for additional teachers in the 
SSE  subsector.  Another  priority  is  to  revise  the  content  of  teacher  education  programs, 
adjusting  them  to  the  new  curricula  and  giving  more  emphasis  to  pedagogy  and  teaching 
practice.  
 
34. 
In-service  teacher  training  is  conducted  at  the  14  regional  in-service  teacher  training 
institutes (RITTIs). At the national level, CIESD provides pedagogical support for the staff of the 
RITTIs  as  well  as  in-service  training  for  education  managers  and  school  principals.  Present 
standards require all staff categories to receive at least 156 hours of in-service training every 3-
5  years  (depending  on  category).  RITTIs  are  functioning  at  about  only  60%  of  their  training 
capacity,  reflecting  low  participation  in  training  courses.  Access  to  in-service  training  is 
particularly  limited  for  teachers  serving  in  remote  areas,  especially  for  female  teachers,  who 
experience difficulties attending courses for a variety of reasons including cost, travel time, and 
family obligations. MOPE’s priority is to expand opportunities for in-service training by improving 

  

9

the  flexibility  of  the  current  system  and  introducing  new  delivery  modes  such  as  distance 
education (DE). Insufficient duration of training, inadequate qualification of instructors, and the 
lack  of  educational  equipment  and  instructional  resources  are  other  critical  issues  to  be 
addressed for improvement of in-service teacher training.  
 
35. 
School  supervision  and  teacher  support  functions  are  performed  by  district  inspectors 
and  methodologists  and  by  school  principals. In principle, inspectors effect school control and 
supervision  and  are  responsible  for  verifying  schools’  adherence  to  national  standards  and 
regulations; methodologists, specialized by subject, have a teacher support and advisory role, 
and should evaluate teachers’ ability to deliver the new educational contents; principals provide 
professional guidance and coaching to teachers and monitor their job performance. In practice, 
however,  the  responsibilities  of  inspectors,  methodologists,  and  principals  are  not  clearly 
delineated. Recent cuts in the number of district inspectors have left methodologists unprepared 
to  take  up  duties  formerly  assumed  by  inspectors.  Most  methodologists  and  principals  cannot 
effectively play their teacher support role, as they have not mastered new subject content and 
have never been exposed to new methods of teaching. A new system for training of district staff 
that  clearly  demarcates  responsibilities  by  position  is  becoming  urgent  to  restore  the  school 
inspection system and improve teacher support. 
 

6. 

Service Conditions of Education Staff 

 
36. 
Teacher morale and motivation declined seriously after independence, but seem to have 
improved  in  recent  years  thanks  to  the  efforts  made  by  the  Government  to  improve  the 
conditions  of  teachers.  Unlike  in  many  other  countries  of  the  FSU,  teachers  in  Uzbekistan 
generally  enjoy  stable  on-time payment of salaries; regular salary increases compensating for 
price  inflation;  and  a  generous  system  of  incentives  and  benefits,  including  discounted use of 
utilities  services,  free  housing  in  rural  areas,  free  medical  service,  and  three  months  of  paid 
holiday.  However,  the  recruitment  of  teachers  for  remote  areas  remains  problematic,  which 
suggests  that  the  package  of  incentives  and  benefits  should  be  reviewed  for  particular 
categories of staff. More than low pay, poor teaching environments, lack of materials, and, for 
many  teachers,  difficulties  in  coping  with  multigrade  classes  have  been  the  critical  factors 
impeding their motivation.

1. 

Funding Sources and Budget Allocations 

 
39. 
Since  independence  and  despite  tight  budgetary  conditions,  the  education  sector  has 
accounted  for  roughly  8%  of  GDP,  a  high  level  by  international  standards,  indicating  a 
substantial  effort  to  support  education.  The  share  of  education  in  total  public  recurrent 
expenditures  has  remained  at  or  above  21%  since  1995.  Almost  90%  of  total  education 
expenditure  comes  from  the  central  (Republican)  budget,  either  directly  (for  financing  higher 
education  institutions  and  ALs),  or  through  transfers  to  regional  governments  (for  primary  and 
secondary schools, and PCs). The remaining 10% is financed through tax revenues generated 
by local governments. Funding for noncompulsory levels of education (i.e., preschool and higher 
education)  relies  in  part  on  extrabudgetary  sources,  namely  payments  made  directly  to 
institutions  by  students,  families,  companies,  etc.  Extrabudgetary  revenues  account  for  about 
one  third  of  total  expenditures  by  higher  education  institutions,  and  are  comprised  primarily  of 
university fees paid by employers for “contract students” (distinguished from “budget students” 
who receive scholarships and in some instances stipends from MOHSSE) .12 
 
40. 
As  shown  in  Appendix  4,  the  subsector  distribution  of  public  recurrent  expenditure  on 
education changed significantly beginning in 1998. With the phase-in of NPPT implementation, 
the  share  allocated  to  SSE  increased  substantially  at  the  expense  of  basic  education.  SSE 
accounted  for  20.2%  of  total  education  spending  in  2001  against  13.6%  in  1997.  Another 
marked  feature  of  education  budgets  is  the  relatively  low  share  allocated  to  personnel  costs 
(between  55-61%  since  1998)  and  to  materials  and  equipment.  In  contrast,  social  transfers 
(such  as  scholarships,  stipends,  and  food)  have  commanded  fairly  large  shares,  especially  at 
noncompulsory education levels, putting a heavy burden on educational budgets. Stipends still 
account  for  about  30%  of  public  spending  on  both  higher  education  and  TVE,  and  meals 
represent  almost  one  half  of  public  spending  on  preschool.  This  pattern,  which  reflects  the 
Soviet  era  legacy  of  generous  subsidies  to  students,  should  also  be  reconsidered  on  equity 
grounds, as it tends tend to disproportionately benefit the more affluent parts of the population 
living  in  urban  areas.  The  structure  of  education  budgets  by  cost  category  is  due  to  change 
significantly with the anticipated increases in teacher salaries, the elimination of stipends in the 
new SSE system, and the progressive reduction in the number of budget students.

2. 

Efficiency and Equity in the Utilization of Resources 

 
41. 
As noted in para. 23, budget allocations and personnel deployment are based on central 
norms  inherited  from  the  Soviet  era.  Small  institutional  size,  and  low  teaching  loads,  
pupil:teacher  ratios,13    and  pupil:nonteaching  staff  ratios  suggest  that  savings  and  efficiency   
gains can be realized without affecting educational access or quality. Conscious about the need 
for improving cost efficiency in education, the Government has made some attempts to review 
staffing and budgeting norms. The maximum class size was increased from 30 to 35 students, 
and  teachers  were  allowed  to  work  up  to  1.5  times  the  normal  workload.  Several  resolutions 
imposing  downsizing  of  the  apparatus  of  the  public  administration  were  issued  since  1999.  In 
2001, a government decree called for a further 16% reduction in the number of civil servants. In 
general, such staff cuts in the education sector have been allocated without any assessment of 
the  relative  shortages  or  surpluses  of  personnel,  by  category  and  level  of  administration, and 
this  has  weakened  the  capacity  of  the  administration  to  deliver  services  and  manage  the 
reforms.  
 
Both  MOPE  and  MOHSSE  have  experienced  drastic  cuts  in  personnel.  In  contrast, 
42. 
central or Republican institutes and the RITTIs were protected. In regional and district offices, a 
large number of positions funded by the central budget were eliminated, and local governments 
had  to  fill  some  vacancies  using  their  own  resources.  Reviewing  the  functions  of  the  central 
institutes  and  rationalizing  their  personnel,  streamlining  the  in-service teacher training system, 
and  strengthening  the  two  education  ministries  and  regional  administration  seem  to  be 
appropriate directions for future redeployment of administrative personnel. These assumptions,  
however, will need to be confirmed in a comprehensive review, performed at the various levels 
of the administration covering staff numbers, status, functions, and tasks.  
 
43. 
There is also some scope for rationalizing the school network by  exploring the potential 
for  developing  multigrade  teaching,  multiple  subject  teaching,  double  shifting,  and  school 
grouping.  Teaching  and  nonteaching  staff  requirements  should  be  determined  in  light  of  new 
norms and the preparation of a new school map. At  the SSE level, simple projections suggest 
that  considerable  savings  and  efficiency  gains  can  be  achieved  by  increasing  the  envisaged 
size of ALs and PCs, and adjusting the boarding capacity to current and foreseen needs. 
 
44. 
Another  important  equity  concern  in  the  distribution  of  financial  resources  is  that  all 
regions  of  Uzbekistan  do  not  have  the  same  resource  base  to  deliver  basic  education  as  the 
result of differences in local level tax revenues. Per pupil expenditure varies considerably across 
regions, from about SUM11,000 in Namangan Region to SUM19,000 in Navoiy Region. This is 
likely to result in variations in the quality of the education provided. Budget transfers from central 
to  local  governments  are  needed  to  compensate  for  poorer  regions’  lower  potential  to  raise 
private funds and mobilize community support. Greater regional autonomy in managing budget 
allocations (flexibility vis-à-vis central norms) would also likely result in an improved utilization of 
resources. Another equity issue relates to the current system of direct student support, which is 
both  excessively  expensive  and  ineffective  in  reaching  the  poor  and  vulnerable  groups  of  the 
population. Improved targeting of beneficiaries in stipend and scholarship programs, based on 
objective socioeconomic criteria, is particularly important in this respect.

3. 

Financial Sustainability 

 
45. 
The  capital  investment  costs  of  the  NPPT  are  considerable.  The  Government  initially 
planned to invest about $3 billion equivalent in the expansion of the SSE system, accounting for 
an  estimated  40%  of  the  public  investment  plan  during  1999-2005.  Recently,  however,  the 
Government  decided  to  extend  the  time  frame  for  the  construction  of  the  network  of  new  PCs 
and ALs to 2009. Most of this funding is expected to come from local taxes raised by regional 
governments.  This  represents  a  considerable  effort  on  the  part  of  the  regions  and  a  drastic 
restructuring  of  their  budgets.  On  the  recurrent  expenditure  side,  the  anticipated  increases  in 
personnel  costs  (additional  teachers  for  the  SSE  subsector  and  payroll  increases)  will  put 
additional  pressure  on  education  budgets.  In  addition  to  the  aforementioned  adjustment  in  the 
scale  and  time  frame  of  SSE  expansion  plans,  key  revisions  must  be  made  in  system wide 
norms to enhance the financial sustainability of the NPPT.  
 
46.  Mobilizing new sources of finance for education and improving efficiency in the utilization 
of public resources are two challenges to be addressed to enhance the viability of the reform. In 
the first place, areas where substantial savings and efficiency gains could be made should be 
identified. Cost savings should be sought in almost all budget categories, including (i) salaries 
and  related  expenses  (by  reviewing  norms  regarding  class  size,  staffing  levels,  and  teaching 
loads),  (ii)  social  transfers  (by  better  targeting  direct  subsidies  such  as  stipends),  (iii) 
construction and maintenance costs (by reviewing the school map, upgrading existing buildings, 
and reducing boarding facilities).  
 
47. 
In addition, appropriate strategies aimed at diversifying sources of finance for education 
have to be worked out. Private-public partnerships have been successfully encouraged with the 
new  law  on  the  financing  of  education  institutions,  allowing  schools  to  raise  and  manage 
extrabudgetary funds. The corporatization of the textbook publishing and printing industry is also 
under  way  as  the  Government  abolished  the  system  of  free  textbook  provision  and  central 
procurement. Nongovernment initiatives in the provision of educational services at the preschool 
and  higher  education  levels  should  be  further  encouraged.  Cost-sharing  or  cost-recovery 
mechanisms  in  the  public  education  system  should  be  developed  at  the  SSE  and  university 
levels, with appropriate measures to offset any possible detrimental effect on access.  
 
D. 
 
48. 
The principal constraint and risk facing the reform is social support. Measures required 
to  improve  system  efficiency  frequently  entail  short-term  losses  for  certain  stakeholders,  and 
thus  may  face  resistance  from  within  the  education  system  (e.g.,  staff  retrenchment  and 
redeployment,  increased  teacher  workload,  reduced  budget  allocations  for  stipends  and 
scholarships,  closing  of  schools,  abolition  of  the  system  of  free  textbook  provision).  In  light  of 
these risks, the Government has adopted a gradual and phased approach to reform. Particular 
attention has been given to mitigating the impact of introducing user charges upon the poor (for 
instance, free textbook provision was continued for certain categories of pupils), while teacher 
salaries and benefits have been protected.  
 
49. 
Institutional  development  and  capacity-building  needs  pose  a  second  set  of  sector 
constraints.  At  the  central  level,  strengthening  national  capacities  in  policy  formulation  and 
strategic  planning  is  critical  to  the  successful  implementation  of  the  reform.  In  particular,  
implementation  modalities  for  reform  must  be  further  refined  to  become  viable  (financially 
sustainable, technically and pedagogically sound) as well as better integrated into a full-fledged 
development  strategy  for  education.  Coordination  among  agencies  responsible  for  reform

E. 
 
51. 
Since independence, education has maintained a prominent place in the Government’s 
reform  agenda.  As  in  other  economic  and  social  spheres,  a legal and centralized approach to 
reform  was  adopted,  culminating  in  1997  with  the  adoption  of  a  new  Education  Act  and  the 
endorsement of the NPPT by parliament. The reform process has been characterized by a top-
down approach, which may have weakened the sense of ownership and understanding of the 
reform,  even  within  the  administration.  A  large  number  of  presidential  decrees  and  ministerial 
orders  have  been  issued  since  the  adoption  of  the  NPPT  in  order  to  provide  guidance  to 
agencies  on  the  implementation  of  specific  reform  measures.  Evidently,  however,  the 
proliferation of legal measures, very often too narrowly focused on specific tasks or clienteles, 
cannot substitute for a well-prepared sector development strategy. The reform process could be 
enhanced  by  promoting  more  systemic,  technical,  and  participatory  approaches  based  on 
dialogue and consultation with educational stakeholders and civil society.  
 
52. 
The  Government  views  the  NPPT  as  a  unique  model  aimed  at  establishing  a  modern 
national  education  system  meeting  both  international  standards  and  the  requirements  of  a 
market  economy  in  a  democratic  society.  Fifteen  strategic  directions  or  broad  principles  are 
stipulated in the NPPT, among which 7 are directly linked to the thrusts of the ESDP: (i) reform 
of educational content, (ii) integration of industry and education, (iii) development of interaction 
between  science  and  education,  (iv)  training  and  retraining  of  education  personnel,  (v) 
autonomy  and  self-sufficiency  of  educational  institutions,  (vi)  promotion  of  private  funding  and 
foreign  assistance  to  education,  and  (vii)  development  of  new  educational  technologies  and 
methods.  
 
53.  Most  decrees  elaborate  on  specific  actions  required  in  key  reform  areas  such  as  (i) 
quality  improvement  (e.g.,  preparation  of  new  basic  education  standards,  plans  for  the 
introduction of the new generation of latin-script textbooks, norms on sanitation and hygiene in 
schools,  creation  of  the  Ustoz  Foundation  to  promote  teacher  retraining  abroad);  (ii)  SSE 
expansion (e.g., plans for the construction of new PCs and ALs, norms on equipment, allocation 
of  plots  of  land  to  agricultural  PCs);  (iii)  modernization  and  decentralization  of  management 
systems (e.g., establishment of monitoring units in agencies, financing of education institutions, 
use  of  extrabudgetary  resources,  establishment  of  school  boards);  (iv)  budget  rationalization 
(e.g.,  instructions  on  staff  reductions,  abolition  of  the  system  of  free  provision  of  textbooks, 
elimination of stipends for SSE students); and (v) protection of special groups, the poor, and the 
vulnerable  (e.g.,  salary  increases  of  education  personnel,  free  provision  of  textbooks  and

Overall,  external  assistance  to  education  is  rather  modest  in  Uzbekistan,  involving  a

US,  Japan,  and  Germany,  have  supported  domestic  and  overseas  training  programs  for  post-

56.

indirectly  benefit  that  subsector  inc lude  initiatives  in  democracy  and  civic  education  (Soros

57.

preparing and implementing loans and technical assistance (TA) activities. The SSE project and 
the  Japan  Bank  for  International  Cooperation-supported  project  are  implemented  in  parallel, 
sharing a common project implementation unit (PIU) and employing coordinated implementation 
strategies. While  at  the  project  level,  coordination  of  external  assistance  can  work  effectively,

consultation  with  the  Government.  This  has  been  detrimental  to  planning  and  integrating

but these have remained ad hoc consultations largely oriented towards fund-raising rather than 
policy dialogue and long-term planning.

61. 
Lessons learned from ADB operations in the education sector in Uzbekistan point to the 
necessity  to  provide  adequate  backstopping  to  executing  agencies  in  all  areas  of  project 
management.  The  absorptive  capacity  of  executing  agencies  (notably  understaffed)  and  their 
experience with the procedures of external development partners remain weak. The capacity of 
government agencies to recruit and retain project staff is also limited, given both the scarcity of 
personnel  with  the  necessary  skills  mix  (in  particular,  good  command  of  English)  and  the  low 
level  of  salary  offered  in  the  administration.  Excessively  bureaucratic  decision-making 
processes, absence of delegation of authority to the level of project implementors, and deficient 
intra-Government coordination are other features of the administrative system that can cause 
important delays in routine project activities such as recruitment of consultants, procurement of 
goods,  and  disbursements.  Access  to  information  also  follows  strict  procedures,  remaining  de 
facto  restricted  and  difficult.  Essential  data  and  statistics,  often  readily  available  and  widely 
disseminated in other countries, can be considered confidential in Uzbekistan. This peculiarity, 
combined  with  the  opacity  and  complexity  of  information  (especially  financial),  has  rendered 
more challenging the policy advisory role of ADB. Paras. 146-150 provide details on how these 
lessons were integrated into the design and implementation arrangements of the ESDP.

1. 

Modernizing Structure, Contents, and Processes of Education  

a. 

Streamlining of the Education Structure  

 
73. 
As part of the overall education restructuring effort, the SSE system must become more 
flexible and better articulated, with basic education on the one hand and higher education on the 
other. The main concern is to improve the short-term employability of SSE graduates as well as 
their trainability and capacity to adjust to changing technologies and labor market conditions. To 
this  end,  overspecialization  of  SSE  establishments  must  be  avoided  and  instructional  content 
should prioritize knowledge and skills that can be applied in a variety of contexts and industries. 
A  more  flexible  and  cost-effective  concept  of  TVE  and  training  must  be  developed  to 
complement the formal SSE system. SSE flexibility and external efficiency will be enhanced by 
(i) reviewing the projected balance between the general stream and the vocational stream, i.e., 
the balance between AL and PC graduates; (ii) strengthening the general education content  of 
the three-year programs delivered in PCs; (iii) developing specialized short-term courses in PCs 
(in  particular  apprenticeship  programs  run  in  collaboration  with  local  businesses);  (iv)  granting 
more pedagogical autonomy to institutions so as to allow them to better tailor their programs to 
local  contexts  and  employment  situations;  and  (v)  facilitating  access  of  PC  graduates  to 
university education. The Government will review SSE expansion plans and strategies along the 
above lines.  
 
74. 
The  Government  will  also  prepare  a  master  plan  for  reforming  higher  education, 
acknowledging  the  need  to  (i)  reorganize  the  subsector  in  a  less  fragmented  way  by 
encouraging grouping of institutions as well as cooperation for teaching and research, (ii) review

course  offerings  in  line  with  actual  needs  and  demand,  (iii)  develop  fair  and  transparent 
admission mechanisms and procedures, and (iv) enhance teaching quality.  
 

b. 

Curriculum Review and Educational Quality Monitoring  

 
75. 
The  Government  has  granted considerable priority to setting new education standards, 
revising curricula, and introducing a new generation of latin-script textbooks. Yet, it recognizes 
that curriculum and textbook development reforms are long-term processes and that continued 
efforts are necessary to further modernize educational content and method. A comprehensive 
review  of  the  basic  education  curriculum  will  be  carried  out,  the  objective  being  to  further 
strengthen the acquisition of fundamental knowledge and the development of aptitudes such as 
critical thinking, problem solving, and creativity.  
 
76. 
At the same time, efforts will be pursued to increase the availability and affordability of 
textbooks in basic education. To this end, MOPE will (i) continue to encourage competition and 
modernization  in  the  textbook  publishing  industry,  (ii)  reduce  the  number  of  textbook  titles 
required in basic education, and (iii) implement a textbook rental system. At the SSE level, the 
implementation  of  the  new  standards  and  curricula  will  be  gradually  completed,  and  new 
instructional materials and textbooks will be developed. 
 
Current  systems  for  assessing  education  quality  need  to  be  reoriented  towards 
77. 
outcomes  and  achievements,  rather  than  inputs  and  norms.  A  study  on  monitoring of learning 
achievements  will  be  carried  out  by  MOPE.  This  study  will  also  help  identify  adjustments 
required  in  the  basic  education  curriculum.  In  parallel,  the  school  inspection  and  supervision 
system must be strengthened and reoriented towards teaching support. District level education 
administrators,  including  inspectors  and  methodologists  as  well  as  school  principals,  will  be 
retrained in academic supervision and coaching.

Teacher Education  

 
78.

dissemination of modern teaching methods remains a high priority for the Government. Access

provision of equipment and materials for a newly established DE system. New modules will be 
jointly  developed  by  in-service  and  preservice  teacher  training  institutions  and  integrated  into 
their  regular  programs.  The  Government  also  agreed  to  reward  teachers  receiving  DE 
certificates with supplementary allowances.

103.  This  component  will  further  efforts  to  enhance  the  autonomy  of  schools  and  reduce

104.  The first subcomponent will encourage the active involvement of communities in school

selected communities will receive training and briefing. This subcomponent will also feature the 
establishment of the SIF to support resource mobilization for schools located in deprived areas.

finance  school  improvement  initiatives  formulated  by  the  community.  Supported  by  a  national-
level  SIF  Coordinator,  SIF  officers  will  be  appointed  in  each  region,  working  closely  with  local

105.  The  second  subcomponent  consists  of  an  upgrading  program  for  the  500  poorest 
schools,  incorporating  findings  from  the  school  and  community  survey.  It  will  comprise 
rehabilitation of facilities (heating, sanitation, safety hazards, etc.) combined with the provision

It  is  proposed  that  ADB  support  the  Government’s  education  reform  package  by 
providing a loan of $70 million from its ordinary capital resources (OCR). The borrower will be 
the Republic of Uzbekistan. The loan will have an amortization period of 15 years, including a

tranches of respectively $30 million, $20 million, and $20 million.  
 
113.  Factors that have been considered in determining the amount of the Program loan are (i) 
the relative importance of the education sector (in terms of public spending and number of civil 
servants) and the rising trend of public spending on education following adoption of the NPPT; 
(ii) the scope and strength of the reform package in the education sector, and in particular the 
acceleration  of  reforms  in  2001;  and  (iii)  the  estimated  short-  and  medium-term adjustment 
costs of the reforms.  
 
114.  The  loan  amount  is  roughly  equivalent  to  the  adjustment  costs  of  the  sole  measures 
included in the policy matrix during the program period and not yet initiated by the Government.  
The breakdown of the estimated adjustment costs  of the principal policy measures comprises (i) 
compensation, retraining, and relocation of redundant staff ($13.1 million); (ii) salary increases, 
allowances,  and  incentive  schemes  for  particular  categories  of  teachers  ($17.6  million);  (iii) 
budget  transfers  to  poor  regions  ($27.2  million);  and  (iv)  direct  support  to  students  from  poor 
families ($4.6 million). Costs of other measures of the policy matrix, including research, studies 
and consultations related to policy developments, education quality monitoring, and curriculum 
evaluation are estimated at roughly $10 million.

VI. 

BENEFITS AND RISKS 

Expected Impacts 

 
A. 
 
144.  The  policy  reforms  supported  by  the  ESDP  will  generate  economic  and  social  benefits 
by improving efficiency and equity in the distribution of educational resources (financial, human, 
and  physical),  quality  of  instruction,  and  institutional  development.  The  ESDP  benefits  will 
accrue primarily from (i) reduction of operating costs following rationalization of the network of 
schools;  (ii)  savings  in  total  payroll  through  downsizing  and  redeployment  measures;  (iii) 
savings  on  expenses  on  scholarships  and  stipends  in  higher  education  through  improved 
targeting; (iv) improved performance of teachers, who will be better trained and motivated with 
new  incentives;  (v)  improved  teaching-learning  environments,  especially  in  poverty-affected 
areas, resulting in higher student achievements and improved retention; (vi) improved capacities

Risks and Safeguards 

to  manage  education  reforms  at  the  central,  local,  and  school  levels;  (vii)  improved  capacity 
utilization  of  existing  in-service  teacher  training  institutions;  and  (viii)  augmentation  of  teacher 
training capacity and reduction in the cost per trainee through the adoption of DE modalities. An 
economic analysis of the ESDP is presented in Appendix 18.  
 
145.  The immediate beneficiaries of the ESDP will be (i) roughly 250,000 school teachers, (ii) 
staffs  of  the  RITTIs  and  of  the  IP  and  FPs,  (iii)  roughly  10,000  school  principals  and  district 
education administrators; (iv) staff and pupils of 500 rehabilitated schools (over 5 % of schools 
nationwide) located in the most deprived areas, and (v) staffs and pupils of about 1,000 schools 
accessing  SIF  resources.  The  ultimate  beneficiaries  of  the  ESDP  will  be  the  6  million children 
enrolled  in  basic  education,  whose  schooling  will  become  more  relevant  and  whose  learning 
environment will become more stimulating.  
 
B. 
 
146.  Low  government  commitment  to  reform,  weak  ownership  of  the  policy  package, 
insufficient  consultation  with  the  Government,  and  overly  complex  and  ambitious  policy 
conditionalities  are  considered  the  major  risks  of  policy-based  lending.  There  have  been 
instances where the Government suddenly shifted policies and made decisions of a legal nature 
without  proper  feasibility  assessment  and  implementation  capacity.  The  ESDP  formulation 
process  attempted  to  minimize  these  risks  in  several  ways:  (i)  the  ESDP  policy  framework  is 
well articulated with the NPPT, which received political commitment at the highest level; (ii) the 
duration of the Program, the number of tranches, and the phasing policy actions conform with 
the  gradual  approach  to  change  adopted  in  Uzbekistan;  and  (iii)  consultation  on  a  detailed 
policy matrix started at an early stage of ESDP preparation; concentrated on a few core reforms 
(building  upon  the  findings  of  other  ADB-supported  TAs);  and  involved  IASC,  whose 
composition remained stable. The articulation between policy actions and project interventions 
of the ESDP gives additional safeguards as regards the implementability of the reform package. 
Measures  of  an  institutional  or  legal  nature  indispensable  to  the  implementation  of  the  Project 
have  been  inserted  in  the  policy  matrix.  Conversely,  the  Project  will  support  policy studies to 
ensure that policy changes are appropriately designed and their feasibility fully assessed from 
the financial, institutional, and educational perspectives. The policy matrix also articulates ESDP 
reform actions with interventions supported by other ongoing ADB operations.  
 
147.  The  provision  of  counterpart  funds  and  staff  in  a  timely  manner  is  another  major  risk 
inherent to ADB operations in Uzbekistan. This risk has been minimized by the requirement of 
upfront  actions  by  the  Government  regarding  establishment  of  the  project  management  and 
monitoring  structure  (establishment  of  IASC,  PIU,  and  ERIMU).  The  DE  expert  positions, 
already endorsed by the Government, are expected to be filled by qualified education personnel 
(reassigned primarily from the RITTIs) so that the additional burden on the government budget 
will be kept minimal (reflecting only the salary differential). The recurrent cost implications of the 
Project have been carefully identified and reviewed by the Government. 
 
148.  Transparency  and  accuracy  of  data  (in  particular  for  monitoring  purpose)  constitute 
another major problem resulting from both the noted deficiencies in existing information systems 
and  low  analytical  capacities.  Poor  quality  and  low  policy  relevance of indicators may lead to 
inaccurate analyses and possible mistargeting of interventions. This risk is considered limited in 
view  of  the  assistance  that  TA  2947-UZB  has  already  extended  and  will  further  provide  in  the 
areas of monitoring of education sector reforms in general and ESDP monitoring in particular.
